title: All blog posts are fetched from a JSON file

fullSummary: I've also experimented with doing this from a local server via the WordPress CMS. It worked beside some issues with media files. title: Approach to CSS
shortSummary: Focus has been on responsiveness and selector experimentation.
fullSummary: The site has one global stylesheet plus one per individual page.
content: Since all pages vary in content, and I wanted to experiment with different layouts and behaviors, I’ve decided to place the media queries in the page-specific stylesheets.
This process has given valuable insights into the cascading feature of CSS.

title: Optimizing for page speed is more fun than it sounds!
shortSummary: I got my page loading speed down by 45% with two simple steps.
fullSummary: I’ve spent time in the browser’s Network tab, simulating page loads on slow connections without the use of cache. This has been educational on the loading mechanisms of browsers and gives a clear view of the importance of compressed images and documents.
content: By using separate CSS files for the unique styles for each page and compressing images, I reduced page load speed by over 45%.

title: My methods for this project
shortSummary: A brief insight into my approach to this school project!
fullSummary: My goal with this project has been to gain fluency with CSS targeting, flexbox, grid, and semantic HTML.
content: I’ve approached this by attempting to use as few classes and content divider elements as possible. Instead, I’ve experimented creatively with CSS selectors and computer-readable elements.

By doing this, I now feel that I see more clearly where classes and dividers are helpful and how much I can do without them for this type of site. I found it especially interesting to see the usefulness of working with low specificity.
A horizontally spread hierarchy of elements makes it easier to keep the site manageable when classes and ids are needed.
